You know those games where everything is perfect? The music is awesome, the play feels great, there's a bunch of variety and it never gets old because every time you play a level again you try doing something different that changes the whole thing?

Yeah, me neither. Or at least I didn't until I tried this game.
The game revolves around... Well, it differs between levels. Sometimes you're making a heist, sometimes you're rescuing someone, and sometimes you're simply getting the f--k out of there.

The game is well balanced with multiple characters, each with different pros and cons. One of my personal favorites, the pickpocket, has a little pet monkey that follows him and gets coins for him. See that coin just out of reach because you'd trigger an alarm to get it? Let monkey Hector get it.
Then there's, say, the cleaner. See a guard blocking your way? He can just sneak up on him and put him to sleep with good ol' clorophorm.
Then there's a locksmith, that, you guessed it, picks locks, safes, ATMs, everything twice to three times as fast as everyone else.
Then there's a looko-- you get the point.

The music also plays a part, mostly because it's 1- Dynamic and 2-Wonderful.
Seriously, you can just see some of the music in this game by going in this link: http://austinwintory.bandcamp.com/album/monaco-gentlemans-private-collection-bundle
This music was made by the same guy who made the music to Journey. And we all know how wonderful that turned out.

The game also has a full fledged workshop with a level editor that, while awkward at first, has literally every single thing in the actual game. See something in game? You can do it in the editor too. In fact, I'm pretty sure it's the same editor they used to make the levels in the game.

But don't be fooled by it's cartoonish graphics, because under that pixelated looking exterior, is a whole story full of drama, plot twists, foreshadowing... And you can play the piano. Yes, that's right, you can play on a f--king piano. With friends. There's even an achievement for doing so.

My point is, what are you doing still reading this? Seriously, this is a huge wall of text. Unless you skipped straight to the end. Either way, stop reading this, and go buy the game. Now. I want more friends to play with me, because, you know. The more the merrier!

reviewText:
Imagine if old GTA games, Chip's Challenge, and Oceans 11 all stumbled into a blender owned by a Lego man.

Boy what a mess that would be. Thankfully, Monaco is 'not' a mess, but rather, a stealth heist game in which you and up to three other thieves band together to plunder the money of a variety of facilities in and around Monte Carlo, everything ranging from Casinos to Hospitals to High Security Prisons, being represented.

The game's two virtues are its deceptive level of gameplay depth, and its humorous design aesthetic. It's the personality hidden behind the neon pixels that at first attracts one to this game--the perplexingly simple yet expressive character designs go along with the frantic piano ragtime and silly french NPC voices, to be extremely memorable. You'll laugh as your little colorful lego thief pees in a toilet, wiggles their hands to hack a PC hollywood style, or hugs a wall and takes deep, ragged breaths after being shot--to the accompaniment of bloodied footprints left in their step. And as your little Mr. Pink dies from that one guard who peaks just inside your hiding place to bop you with a wrench, they explode into a neon pink colored skeleton, and the music thuds to an abrupt halt--only for the music to pick up again where it left off, once your fellow criminals put your guts back in (to the sound of hilarious squishing noises).

As for the gameplay, it's definitely the part that keeps you playing Monaco, long after you're familiar with its pretty pixel face. On the one hand, you can be a sneaky, super subtle player who never gets caught, never trips a trap, never fires a shot. It can at first be a difficult process to do so, as you're forced to learn by trial and error (due to the game's sparse tutorial elements) how to remain undetected.

On the flip side, however, Monaco, unlike some of its compatriots in the sneak-em-up genre, never trips over the hurdle of forced stealth. You can shoot people down in a bloody Scarface-esque machinegun massacre, lure guards and civilians into side areas off patrol and give them a wrench over the head, 40's femme fatale style, or be a clever ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, cut the circuit breaker in a particularly well-guarded facility, and just 'camp' the power room subduing guards who come with chloroform, while your (debatably) coordinated teammates do the legwork.

In fact, if you're in a hurry, it can sometimes be better just to run aggressively past NPCs, dodging from cover to cover to avoid security agent machinegun fire, or to climb in a vent duct to escape angry attack dogs who are onto your scent, rather than trying to outstealth them. And as a result of this flexibility, at first, it seems like Monaco will be trivially easy to play and win.

But Monaco is a stern teacher, and it knows how to steadily ramp up the difficulty to keep you challenged through around thirty-some different, replayable missions. As you go, new classes and items are introduced to the formula, along with new map features like security-trigger handscans, computer viruses, alarm-triggering ATMs that must be busted open for cash, and more.

The game is incredibly flexible in its approach, and each class is nuanced enough to be distinct from its brethren. (The one class I am not personally fond of is the Pickpocket, which tends to encourage reckless, self-serving tactics over cooperation, at lower levels of play experience.) However, the classes are not so distinct that they cannot all perform basic functions like opening a safe, or hacking a PC--it's just that some classes do these things more efficiently than others. So there will rarely be a point where you play a mission 'exactly' the same as the last time you played it, as you tackle obstacles in a level best suited to whatever class you are playing at the time.

Lastly, there 'is' a story to the game, consisting mostly of text dialogue, but which is filled with humor and an actually relatively intriguing plot, fleshing out the personalities and origins of the thieves you play as. The thieves themselves have some pretty charming tics--the Hacker is constantly making references to PC error codes and computer shorthand terminology, the Gentleman is your 'World's Most Interesting Man', complete with his own little intrigue and espionage plot, the Cleaner is a stoic psychopath who rarely speaks beyond deep heavy breaths, and the Mole has a terse Serbian accent and a Freedom Spoon which he employs with a mixture of bravado and thuggish loyalty.

The game does suffer from a poor matchmaking system, which is a bit prone to lag and connectivity issues. Also, the menu options are a bit confusing, and there is one bug with using a controller that prevents mouse usage until your machine is restarted--so if you tend to use a controller for some games, like Gauntlet or Dark Souls, but prefer a mouse and keyboard for Monaco, you may run into complications where your mouse doesn't want to work to aim guns til you pull a soft reset on your OS.

All in all, I give Monaco a thumbs up. There are a lot of visual tweaks that could probably make finding your way in the maps a bit easier, the story could use some accompanying visuals (even if just still scenes), and the tutorial aspects of the game are sorely lacking even after a custom tutorial map was added--but the game just has so much complexity and charm, that it's hard not to pick it up from time to time, if you can get past those hiccups long enough to get into the meat of the game.

Grab it if you don't have it, and see if you can't wrangle some friends into the heist with you on headsets. At worst, it'll make for an amusing weekend of cartoon criminal hijinx.

A game of intrique, mystery and most importantly, teamwork. Monaco is a game that revolves around a gang of criminals who plan a series of heists to escape from jail, and to escape from the suspicion of the law. Throughout the course of the game, players will choose different and unique character classes (mole, locksmith, cleaner, hacker) who utilize special skills (digging through walls, opening safes, knocking people out, diasbling security systems) and a vast array of thieving tools ranging from shotguns to smokebombs in order to perform heists.

The game features a unique top-down blueprint perspective that, when a good plan goes through, feels like a scene out of the Oceans 11 series. While the game on single player is enough, it's the multiplayer that truly makes this title worth a purchase. Local Co-op and Online Co-op (these are mutually exclusive in this case) let you have fun with friends and strangers, and friendly strangers around the world.

That being said though, multiplayer is also one of the biggest caveats of the monaco experience. Servers can be unreliable at times and the leaderboards seldom update or never record scores, if it all. This can create some frustration since a really fun aspect of Monaco is planning routes and heists and seeing how these strategies stack up against other players. While this game is a personal favorite of mine, I recognize that this type of game isn't for everyone. reviewText:
This is a well built stealth game, a game genre we are lacking in quality.
You have your choice of several characters, each with unique abilities and unique styles to play through the maps.

What this game offers is more variability of gameplay. If you're spotted or set off an alarm, you have options. You can try gunning down the enemies, running around corners, sneaking behind a nearby bush or running for a vent. It takes time to get through them though, time the enemy can pummel or shoot you. Unlike other stealth games, a well planned out escape won't necessarily lead to death if you're clever.

The difficulty curve is really well done. You're consistently unlocking new content and styles of gameplay with every level, the challenge slowly increasing. If you die, it doesn't feel like such a failure compared to other games because you learn. I actually found it fun to die. While playing co-op, death adds an extra layer of difficulty of: How do I get my teammate back up?

The in game dialogue is clever and cheeky. There is strong depth of gameplay here. I even like the basic 2d graphics, it feels uncluttered and consistent compared to other games. The smaller and quality nature of the maps make the game forgiving of failure.

The bad would be finding enough people to play the later levels with, the few co-op games that lag, and dying on the later levels after an arduous journey through four levels.

I highly recommend the game. I give it a solid 8.5.

reviewText:
Pretty amazing game all things considered. It's been around for a year now, so the price is lower than release, and I'm sure you can get it for next to nothing from either a Humble Bundle, or waiting on a Steam sale.

As you can see from previews, it's a top down sneaking/stealing game. You've got eight characters total, each with their own main ability, and a less noticeable side ability. Example, if going by the preview, the Lookout is the expert at Recon, which means when she's sneaking/stationary, everyone gets red icons on the map indicating where guards/civilians are, even when not in vision.
Her secondary power is that she opens ladders/vents 3 times as fast as anyone else. The main power of each class is the draw, but often you'll find the secondary power is incredibly useful as well.

There are a rich amount of stories, though given that this game is a year old now, online co-op can be somewhat hit or miss. There are still players, but you might not be able to get a game every time you look.
Another frustration is that later missions become really very difficult for a solo player to beat. It's always completely possible, though sometimes it requires some extra work. This really is a game that benefits from co-op.

As people have mentioned, getting seen or alerting guards will not be the end of you, and in fact is required sometimes to move guards out of position. That said, later missions in say the 2nd story or the epilogue will punish you quickly for not being stealthy.

Finally, for a small little indie title about pixilated thieves, there is actually a pretty good story being told here. It presents itself as story's being told by one of the thieves in a police interview. As such, the 2nd story is the same heists, but completely changed around, and a step up in difficulty as it's another of the crooks recollection of the tale.
It's up to you to puzzle out the whole truth of what really happened here. The reveal comes in the final mission of story two, but it's easy to miss what happened if you aren't expecting it.

I continue to play this game and highly recommend it for the price it is now (15$, and certainly recommend it on sale)

reviewText:
The level of sneakery in this game is fantastic. You can get through the entire game without being seen, but even if you do get spotted, it's still entertaining running around, ducking into AC vents and evading the security guards.

The best part of the gameplay is its simplicity. You have one item, and the character you choose has one special ability.
The difficulty curve is actually really well-made. You start in levels with just a handful of guards, and eventually reach sprawling levels with lots of automated security systems and attack dogs and stuff.

Amazingly, it works as both a singleplayer and multiplayer experience. It's a lot better in multiplayer, because four people running around knocking people out, setting off alarms, and planting C4 is better than one. But it can stand on its single player experience.

There's a level editor and the developers have released a few new content packs for free, so that's pretty cool.

If you like heist games and general stealthy sneaky hiding-in-bushes and running around stealing stuff, this game is definitely for you.

reviewText: Probably one of the best co-op (local or online) games out there. The stealth mechanics manage to fit well with the generally arcadey feel, as the guards aren't super perceptive, so they can be avoided if you're careful (and sometimes if you aren't!). Stealth playthroughs, especially in singleplayer, are satisfying and tense. However, Monaco is just as fun when you don't try to be stealthy, as you can get into crazy and action-filled situations as you're forced to escape oncoming guards after you trip an alarm or get caught. The AI can be punishing, though, and some enemies, such as shotgun toting Gendarme, are not to be taken lightly. Multiplayer tends to lean towards the more wild approach unless you're working in a two-man crew or everyone is trying to stay on the down-low. You're given the pick of (once you unlock all of them) eight thieves, each with their own unique abilities, all of which are useful. This is another reason why the game shines in multiplayer, because each thief can tackle different situations that others would have trouble with. There's also a good number of equipments which provide the player with some tool that can get help them get the job done, like smoke bombs, shotguns, C4, and EMPs. Monaco has a ton of standard campaign levels with unique settings and good variety, and there's also hundreds of user-made levels, some of which are almost as good as the standard ones. The level editor itself is fairly easy to use once you understand the basics, and there are a couple of really extensive guides on the community page which can help get you started. It's also got a sweet noir style piano soundtrack by Austin Wintory, the guy who made the Journey soundtrack.\n\nNow, all of this comes with, as I see it, one major catch. Monaco is a really old game, as far as indie online co-op games go (it seems). There's a way smaller community base than there was a few years ago, so finding players can be a challenge. Because of this, I'd recommend that you find a friend willing to play with you, or try the local co-op. If neither of those work out for you, try and leave a message on the community board asking for players. From what I've seen, there are some people who would be willing to play.

At first I thought this game was all smoke and mirrors when it came to the game play and graphics, but up until I took the time to actually play this game then I realized the potential it has playing yourself or playing online with others.


The games premise is to rob places without being detected, which seems simple right? The unique portion is working together as each different player or unit has a specific function. There are 8 different classes to unlock while progressing through the game : the locksmith, the pickpocket, the cleaner, the lookout, the mole, the gentleman, the hacker, the redhead. In order, the locksmith can pick locks a lot faster than anyone, the pickpocket is able to acquire coins from a greater distance and doesn't alert guards or trigger alarms, the cleaner can knock out guards and heal faster, the lookout can see a vast majority of whats going on from great distances, the mole can rip through almost any wall (my favorite characteristic!), the gentleman is able to disguise himself, the hacker can disable alarms and spread viruses into computer systems and finally, the redhead who is able to attract enemies and have them open doors for her while not harming other immediate players. Some of these players come when you first start the game while others have to be unlocked as you progress (nothing wrong with that)! Map designs are also very fluid and challenging. Some parts will seem impossible to get by without a helping hand. There is usually always a way though if you're stuck playing solo.


The unique view setting this game provides is the excitement through it's graphics. Although simple in premise, it's very effective in providing a good game play experience (unless you don't like this sort of thing and are bound to stylish 3D graphics). Sounds are absolutely fantastic and as a French speaking individual, it's greatly appreciated. I'm sure those who do not speak French will start picking up a few things as well. The dialogue is okay (I wish they added a bit more) but for the most part it does a good job keeping you on your toes.



I would recommend buying it on sale.

Kind of like a stealth-oriented Hotline Miami, the name of the game in Monaco is to get in, steal an objective, get out, while taking all the dosh along the way. Unlike most stealth games though, Monaco expects you to be caught, and gives you tools to deal with a situation. The characters have different abilities and each one has a different way of handling the same level, giving great replayability.
Single-player and multi-player also have very different methods of approach.
Like all good games, it starts off simple but becomes quite challenging in the end. Getting all of the gold in a level unlocks mirrored, more difficult versions of the levels.
The music is a smooth ragtime piano that changes to fit the action. Haven't heard anything like it in other games.
Comes with a level editor, and the hours of additional play that entails.
I had a ton of fun with this game and I think you will too.

reviewText:
Bottom line, this is Ocean's Eleven: The Game. And that is a hefty recommendation all by itself.

Up to four players choose one of 8 crooks, each with a unique specialty. The Locksmith opens doors and safes quickly, the Cleaner neutralizes people when they're not looking. Then the team must work together to pull off heist objectives, or, more challenging, get every available coin.

The action takes place in a top-down view. Layered systems of security, from dogs and motion sensitive cameras to civilians that alert nearby guards, must be bypassed or defeated to get in, get rich, and get out.

The control scheme is marvelously compact. There is a sneak button and a use-special-item button. There is a button to bring up the HUD and see how much life you have and how many coins remain to be stolen in a level. There is a button for push-to-talk. And there is a control stick. If you want to do something, like unlock a door or hack into a computer, just walk into it.

Online co-op feels magical. Even with strangers, you start to move as a team and think together. And if you don't, hilarity ensues as your careful plans go to pot.

Can't omit the thoughtful graphics and sound design, but the core gameplay is the meat. It is new, and it is fabulous.

A promised map editor will provide endless community content, to be released soon.

In short, a must buy that may define 2013.

reviewText:
Monaco: What's Yours is Mine is, quite simply put, one of the most intelligent games released this year. The tightly structured gameplay is fast and fluid, and the colorful cast (quite literally) of playable characters are great. Everything about the game, from its mechanics to its presentation, to its music and its sound, feels original and fresh. Monaco is a game with a strong sense of self, a game that is acutely aware of its own eccentric identity and not afraid to show it, which is precisely what makes it such a strong title.

In much the same fashion as Hotline Miami and Fez, the incredible art design shows just how much detail there can be in blocky, pixellated graphics. The music is nothing short of masterful, wearing its ragtime, silent-movie inspiration on its sleeve and being all the better for it. The sound design is phenomenal as well, with the typing of keys on a computer, to the whine and sharp snap of a breaker box, to the strange rumbling murmurs of a revive all contributing to the game's singular and unique personality.

The game proves how millions of dollars aren't necessary in creating something fun and original; on the contrary, Monaco is important because it shows how so much can be done with so little. It shows the world that what a game really needs in order to stand out is an identity, something that many mainstream contemporary titles sorely lack. Thanks to the uniqueness and originality that pervades through every aspect of its construction, Monaco: What's Yours is Mine is one of the best, and one of the most important, games released in recent memory. Buy it now if you haven't already.

-Quick Review-
Monaco: What’s Yours Is Mine is a 2d stealth game that is played from the top view the whole time. The game is very random in puzzle nature so it’s difficult to plan for whatever you face in the game. You can play between several different campaigns and also play player-based maps.
-Detailed breakdown review-
Story:  The first campaign you are the Locksmith, tell the story of escaping from prison and trying to make it to a new country and leave his past of crime behind him. Unfortunately the temptation of getting additional wealth starts to pull him away from his initial intentions.
Additional campaigns tell of a more elaborate story, the second campagn is about the Pickpocket, whom is narrating and telling a different story from the Locksmith. There are two more campagns but I haven’t played those yet, because of the increasing difficulty in the puzzles.
(Where are my Ninja stars and places to sneak and hide?  //Goes back to Ninja games)

Game Play: In Monaco you can choose between eight different characters, each with their own ability’s to help them get through the various puzzles. There are useful guides to help you understand more about what the characters do.
To list the basic starting four characters: the locksmith can picklocks really fast, the Pickpocket has a pet monkey that collects loot, the cleaner knocks people out (when they don’t see him), the lookout can detect enemies that are farther away and out of your line of site.

Achievements: The achievements in this game are rather straight forward, but also rather tough. As usual you get several achievements just from beating a few levels, but in the end most of the achievements will require a lot of work to earn. Most can be earned with guides on offline single player. But the rest will require

Price: Monaco: What’s Yours Is Mine costs $14.99, for me that is overpriced, but you could easily get many hours of gaming out of it. If you do get over 20 hours out of the game (and know you love stealth based games and a lot of challenge) it’s probably a fair price.
I feel like it’s not fair for me to say that I don’t recommend the game because of the price, I just really didn’t enjoy the game, but it was a good game and I think it’s worth a try… try the free weekend or a demo or something before you purchase it to know for certain if you like this style of game.

Conclusion: I really thought this game was interesting, different, unique, and added a great amount of challenge compared to most classical stealth games. But this game would be way more fun to play with friends. Even when I played a few games with strangers I enjoyed the fast paced gameplay.
But I really can’t say this game makes it on my top list. I would recommend this game just because I think it deserves a chance, but once again; try it on a free weekend or a demo of some type before you purchase, so you know ahead of time what you’re getting yourself into.

reviewText:
Monaco is a steal at this price
Not going to go into much detail right now but this game is brilliant. Lovely and fairly unique art style with gameplay and story that manages to both fit in perfectly with the visuals and give it a lot of charm. There's a wide range of characters you an play as with each one having their own unique traits and/or abilities that compliment the level design perfectly. Each gives you an entirely different approach to how you move throughout the levels.

In co-op play, only one player can play each character so you have to work out what's best (or the most fun) for the situation and who's playing what. The different characters have great synergy with one another and allow you pull off much more complicated and efficient strategies. This can also lead to the most hectic games you'll see with one mistake causing sheer chaos. Though the single player is great and doesn't suffer from solo play, the co-op is the life of this game and it's where the most replay value will be had.

Classic mode allows you to play as originally intended if you don't want to play with the changes in updates and zombie mode makes everything much more dangerous with much more persistent enemies. If you run out of levels to play then there's a level editor and Steam Workshop support to keep the game lasting as long as you want.

I've only got 2.5 hours of this game on Steam but I purchased this game for the Xbox 360 on release and I've very much enjoyed what I've played. There's a lot more content in the Steam version, it is 100% the better version of the game and it's worth the full price without a doubt.

Grab this game while it's 87% off if you don't own it already. The discount is for both a single copy and the 4 pack. It's a steal at this price and you'll be missing out big time if you don't pick it up.

reviewText:
Monaco is an excellent 4-player co-op game that offers a unique blend of action and puzzle solving. If you're confused by what you're seeing in the store, don't be alarmed. The screenshots and videos don't do this game justice; you have to actually play the game for a bit to get a feeling for what's going on. All that color and chaos comes together nicely when you're playing.

Monaco is decent entertainment as a single-player game, but the single-player game is best used to get familiar with each character at your own speed. Where Monaco really shines is when you get 2-4 people together in co-op mode. Different characters' abilities complement each other in surprising ways, and strategies emerge that simply aren't possible in solo play. Figuring out how to combine different characters' abilities to meet the unique challenges that each level presents is half the fun.

If you don't have Steam friends to play with, you'll be pleasantly surprised by the Monaco community. This is a group that really likes to cooperate, and is patient with new players. The patient, cooperative play style of Monaco appeals to more mature gamers, and the public community really reflects that.

I enthusiastically recommend Monaco. It’s a blast.

reviewText:
Summary: Heist simulator 2013
Multiplayer: 4
Completion: 5 hrs
Cards: Yes
Cloud: Yes

When you were a kid, were you ever dragged to a social gathering and had nothing fun to do there? Monaco is the game I wish I had when I was growing up and taken to play party games with other people.

In Monaco you assemble a team of specialized thieves intent on stealing goods and getting away with it. You have very limited tools to handle opposition, so you must stealth your way to the goods, grab it, and run like hell. It's pretty much as it sounds.

The graphics have a rather simplistic look. They're serviceable, though the saturated palette can make it hard to see things, and is sometimes hard on the eyes. Music is also serviceable. It goes for a sort of ragtime feel, like watching a black and white film.

Gameplay involves a top-down view of the area, much like looking at a blueprint, with security guards whose attention span could give MGS Genome Soldiers a run for their money. Electronic traps and security cameras also seek to alert your presence, but you can disable these should you find their terminal.

If there's one thing Monaco does well, its promote teamwork. The character roles are so different and specialized that the more people you have the better your chances are of pulling this off... provided you work together.

If there's one thing I would like to add to the game, it's having AI party members. I can't always get a party of four, and so I would like to have some meatshiel- I mean scapegoa- I mean accomplices to assist me in my solo capers.

While Monaco isn't the kind of game I would replay for days on end, it does make a fantastic occasional party game. Sure beats playing most board games. I give Monaco a 7.5/10 Thanks spleeno!

reviewText:
Monaco is a great looking artsy game with a great concept and, to a certain extent, this concept works out very well. More in singleplayer than multiplayer.

Think of Monaco as a 1-4 player(s) Pacman-like heist game; collect as many coins as you can, grab some loot and then make a run for it. Sounds great, doesn't it ? Yes, as a concept. In reality it could've been so much better. Let me try to explain.

First of all, I've been waiting for this game to be released for a long time, and now that it has finally been released I can't help but feel disappointed. Why ? Because in co-op the game is just so damn hectic and it's hard to see your location or any location for that matter. There are no instructions on how to use your character and their abilities properly. You can see why that's distracting when you're playing with other people. Your partners have certain expectations and instead of actually helping you're running around making it look like you know what you're doing. But you actually don't know. People (including yourself) will ragequit because of this. They're unforgiving. Sure, not everyone, but a lot of my games have ended that way.

Also, the AI is a bit random from time to time, so there's no right way to finish a level. You need a bit of strategy and also a whole lot of luck. One thing that could instantly make this game better is by simply increasing your field of vision, giving you a better sight while walking around, and giving you more of an idea on what to do next.

The single-player mode is thankfully less hectic, but still doesn't really teach you how to use your abilities properly. In single-player you can't get resurrected (obviously) so, instead, you have a certain amount of lives. Die and you can't use that character anymore and this continues until you run out of characters (i.e. lives).

Now, on the other hand, Monaco has more than enough content and some missions should take you over 30 minutes to finish. They can certainly be fun while playing with  a group of friends.

This little review does make it look like I hate it, but I really don't. I truly like this game, I just wish it was better on certain fronts, or maybe a bit more open to get rid of the chaos entirely.
Make sure you give it a spin if you have a group of friends who you can communicate with, that should certainly help.

[Rating: 80/100]

reviewText:
My only complaint about the game is that the classes are boring. Currently the classes you can play as are: a “locksmith,” a “pickpocket,” a “cleaner,” a “lookout,” a “mole,” a “gentleman,” a “hacker,” a “redhead,” and a “blonde.” Really? No WONDER so few finished the game. The people we played with are just boring. Cliches. Veritable “mehs.”

But it doesn’t have to stay this way. Pocketwatch Games can fix this by replacing these classes with cooler ones. Specifically these:

We can replace the “locksmith” with “Sasha Grey.” The Sasha Grey class makes money by taking many hard tasks simultaneously (often four at a time!). She takes them harder and faster than the other classes and, though they would cause other classes such vertigo that others would vomit, she, at her limits, would just gag and roll her eyes back and ask for more, and with profanities! This class is like a “tank,” and can take great punishment.

As for the “pickpocket,” how about “Jenna Haze”? Jenna Haze has an easy-going, perky personality. She’s the charmer of the group. She’s enthusiastic and energetic, bending over to do almost any task. She also has tan skin. This is useful.

As for “the cleaner,” that can be replaced by “Tori Black.” Not particularly good at anything but above average at everything, you can count on her to do basically anything. And I mean anything. Some of the others may resent her non-specialization—but the absolute value of her skills makes her a force to be watched.

The “lookout”? Let’s replace ‘im with “Lexi Belle.” Don’t let her quiet, high school girl demeanor make you think she’s not willing to do dirty deeds. She’s the innocent-looking one among this group, and you’re going to need her, because, well, everyone else in the group looks a little…suspicious? I think that’s the word. You’re going to need Lexi Belle to balance that look out.

And the “mole.” How about “Jesse Jane”? Having grown up on military bases, this girl has the discipline and experience necessary to get almost any job done (wink wink). She’s a down-to-earth girl; not as sunshine and unicorns as Jenna, but not as hard as Sasha. And she has a mischievous facial expression none of the others have. You really want this girl on the team.

What of the “gentleman”? Well, obviously: James Deen. With his boyish face, athletic physique, and blue eyes, he’s obviously a gentleman. Female guards will look at him and immediately become disarmed (of COURSE there are female guards in this game! Don’t be a sexist!). He has an incredible amount of experience for his age, and unlike many of the other male candidates for the job, well, he can play the “gentleman.” He’s also a good team player; he can work with the rest of the group all night long, and in many positions.

Speaking of which, let’s replace the “hacker” with “Stoya.” Graduating high school at age 16, and being versed in computers and games (plus being a writer), how could we NOT want her on the team? She’s the nerd, and the most rebellious of the group; the proper answer to “the hacker.” Being of Scottish and Serbian ethnicity, she also brings something exotic to the team. How many Scottish, Serbian Americans have you played with?

Now, the “redhead.” Coming out of retirement, we have “Faye Reagan.” Retiring from “the industry” early due to drug problems, Faye in this game gets a second chance at life. She realizes that she just has to focus on being good at what she believes in, which is sharing the wealth that her mind and body are capable of with this team of stars.

And as for the “blonde,” “Kayden Kross.” No longer a performer but rather a director, she will be the leader of our group. This Swedish American writes well (though not as well as Stoya) and, with her French husband and partner in crime Manuel Ferrara, we can expect her to sweep Monaco’s rich men. Or perhaps rich women? (Mr. Ferrera demands that she work only with women for some reason if she DOES have to perform) (we’ll have to keep her away from the James Deen I guess). Kayden also happens to be the most beautiful of the group. Beautiful in that she has an aura of leadership.

And there you have it! Just imagine all these characters in some Monaco mansion, working together all at once! Oh what fun that would be! Pocketwatch games! Give us what we desire!

reviewText:
England are back-to-back under-20 rugby world champions.

The English won an intense Junior World Championship final 21-20 over South Africa at Eden Park in Auckland tonight.

South Africa trailed in four of their five games in the Junior World Championship, coming back to win each of their first three.

It wasn’t to be a fourth time, as England matched South Africa’s muscle, and their backs shone.

Nerves were getting the better of both sides early on, with simply passes missing their mark and drops going to ground.

Kicking was wayward and lineouts were shaky, and neither team was able to calm down.

Handre Pollard gave South Africa an early lead through a penalty, but Billy Burns replied with a penalty for England two minutes later.

After his calm, commanding displays throughout the tournament, it was fitting that Pollard’s brilliance gave South Africa their first try of the match.

His well-weighted chip kick inside the English 22m line bounced perfectly for centre Jesse Kriel who did the rest to score.

South Africa were starting to prove their dominance in the set piece as the half wore on, but England were edging the battle at the breakdown.

The Africans were also winning the tactical kicking battle, with Pollard twice finding touch deep inside the English half.

That’s where lock JD Shickerling was going to work, winning three lineouts against the throw in the first 30 minutes.

English wing Howard Packman seemed to think he was at the wrong World Cup near the end of the second half, taking a dive under minimal contact in chasing a ball he had just kicked ahead.

Aaron Morris drilled a 55 metre penalty for England as time ticked down on the first 40 minutes, pulling his team within four points.

That sparked the English at the end of the half, with a rampaging run from centre Nick Tompkins setting the stage for Nathan Earle to score a try in the corner.

Burns and Pollard exchanged penalties in the opening moments of the second half as both sides looked to find some dominance.

England found it through their forwards, putting pressure on the South Africans they hadn’t dealt with in the tournament to date.

Replacement flanker Joel Conlon scored when England mauled over the South African line, extending the lead to eight with 52 minutes gone.

On the back of the strong foundation in the forwards England were starting to get confidence to throw the ball around, and South Africa were struggling to handle it.

Second-five Harry Sloan, Tompkins, Earle and Packman were finding their way through the line at will, continually keeping South Africa on the back foot.

South Africa were back in it with 63 minutes gone, having barely withstood the pressure from England, scoring a stunning long range try up the left touchline.

It was Kriel with his second of the night, after great work from Henry Purdy breaking past Earle.

Chants of ‘‘Bokke’’ were echoing around Eden Park as South Africa hunted the tournament title, when Pollard kicked a drop goal just wide of the posts with eight minutes remaining.

That kicked proved the clincher, as England kept their composure over the final few minutes to close out the match.

South African captain and first-five Handre Pollard was awarded the IRB World Junior Player of the Year award following the final, beating English wing Nathan Earle, New Zealand’s Tevita Li and Ireland’s Garry Ringrose to the title.

England 21 (Nathan Earle, Joel Conlon tries; Billy Burns con, 2 pens, Aaron Morris pen)

South Africa 20 (Jesse Kriel 2 tries; Handre Pollard 2 con, 2 pens) HT 11-10

reviewText:
Monaco Whats Yours Is Mine

We've all had that fantasy, you know, the one where you plan an elaborate heist, Even if you haven't i'm sure you have at least seen ocean's 11. Sadly if you tried this in real life you would risk going to prison, but fret no more because finally a game has come out where you can do just that (other than payday), without suffering the real life consequences of robbing a bank.

Sound 4/5
Art 5/5
Gameplay 4/5
Story 3/5
Overall 16/20

On the sound spectrum i think I was rather generous as the music is not tremendous (purely my opinion), but there are no horrible sound effects that take away from the experience of the game. Where it really excels in this spectrum is the voice acting. while not much dialogue, the little there is is very funny.

At the quality AAA games are at in this day of age it is hard for small teams to get that same feel, so many go for the retro look. However, just because the graphics aren't of their era doesn't write them off the art category. Even though it may not look real it is still one of most beautifully presented games i have ever seen. they really pushed what they could do with the graphics they had

The gameplay is light, fun and a blast with friends. the high speed robbery is a great mechanic and can only be built on,and with so many different classes to choose from it can take a lot of planning until you and your friends have the perfect bank mugging dream team. you can also go solo if you wish and will still be challenged to a very fun and strategic game. Sometimes you can spend hours trying to get that top spot on the leaderboards and it is a game that suites that competitiveness completely. sadly, this game can get slightly repetitave after playing for a while and the replay value isnt great at this point

The story in this game is good but not great, it is quite simple and engaging but gets quite predictable and you sometimes just skip some dialogues before the level completely. However, the story gets the job done and really is not what this game is focused on. like many retro style games story is an afterthought and that definately shows in Monaco, but it is not bad to a point that it ruins the game

I would recommend this game to anyone who has any taste in games. with all the cookie-cutter fps games there are it is pleasant to see something  innovative and new. It is well worth the money and I think most people would have a good time with it

England are back-to-back under-20 rugby world champions.

The English won an intense Junior World Championship final 21-20 over South Africa at Eden Park in Auckland tonight.

South Africa trailed in four of their five games in the Junior World Championship, coming back to win each of their first three.

It wasn’t to be a fourth time, as England matched South Africa’s muscle, and their backs shone.

Nerves were getting the better of both sides early on, with simply passes missing their mark and drops going to ground.

Kicking was wayward and lineouts were shaky, and neither team was able to calm down.

Handre Pollard gave South Africa an early lead through a penalty, but Billy Burns replied with a penalty for England two minutes later.

After his calm, commanding displays throughout the tournament, it was fitting that Pollard’s brilliance gave South Africa their first try of the match.

His well-weighted chip kick inside the English 22m line bounced perfectly for centre Jesse Kriel who did the rest to score.

South Africa were starting to prove their dominance in the set piece as the half wore on, but England were edging the battle at the breakdown.

The Africans were also winning the tactical kicking battle, with Pollard twice finding touch deep inside the English half.

That’s where lock JD Shickerling was going to work, winning three lineouts against the throw in the first 30 minutes.

English wing Howard Packman seemed to think he was at the wrong World Cup near the end of the second half, taking a dive under minimal contact in chasing a ball he had just kicked ahead.

Aaron Morris drilled a 55 metre penalty for England as time ticked down on the first 40 minutes, pulling his team within four points.

That sparked the English at the end of the half, with a rampaging run from centre Nick Tompkins setting the stage for Nathan Earle to score a try in the corner.

Burns and Pollard exchanged penalties in the opening moments of the second half as both sides looked to find some dominance.

England found it through their forwards, putting pressure on the South Africans they hadn’t dealt with in the tournament to date.

Replacement flanker Joel Conlon scored when England mauled over the South African line, extending the lead to eight with 52 minutes gone.

On the back of the strong foundation in the forwards England were starting to get confidence to throw the ball around, and South Africa were struggling to handle it.

Second-five Harry Sloan, Tompkins, Earle and Packman were finding their way through the line at will, continually keeping South Africa on the back foot.

South Africa were back in it with 63 minutes gone, having barely withstood the pressure from England, scoring a stunning long range try up the left touchline.

It was Kriel with his second of the night, after great work from Henry Purdy breaking past Earle.

Chants of ‘‘Bokke’’ were echoing around Eden Park as South Africa hunted the tournament title, when Pollard kicked a drop goal just wide of the posts with eight minutes remaining.

reviewText:
I wasn't sure what to expect from Monaco, whether it would be more arcade or more realistic. And I've come to the conclusion it's a little bit of both.

When you open the game, the menu itself moves very nicely, with graphics flowing in the background. Right off the bat, there are multiple gamemode options. I dove right into “Campaign” mode, and, like many other games, it showed me the first mission I could complete in color, and all the others were grayed out. However, what I really liked about playing Monaco's campaign, is that I could join/start a lobby, have up to three other people with me, and could stay in that lobby and keep selecting episodes instead of having to join a new lobby for each episode.

The gameplay itself is very nice. You start on the first episode by choosing one of four characters, each with their own perk. As you progress through levels, you gain more characters. The game loads very quickly, after you depart from the neat lobby menu of changing options (which is always fun). It is a top-down game, but there are obviously good reasons for that. On the top, directions will be given as to what you have to do, so that it's never confusing, and the goal is to sneak past the police/guards to get to the object the heist was started for and all the spare money along the way. There are weapons to pick up from time to time, but I found that running away from guards and hiding in a room for a few seconds keeps them off your scent.

Pros:
Menus move very smoothly.
The graphics, being a top-down game, are pretty decent.
The objectives are always clear.
You can stay in the same lobby for as many levels as you choose.
All campaign levels can be completed in either singleplayer or multiplayer.
The controller support is amazing, and I actually prefer to use the controller.
There's Steam Workshop to download new levels to play.
It's local co-op too, so it's good for a party with friends if you have more than one controller.

Cons:
Gun reloading is very obnoxious. It shouldn't take 10 seconds for one bullet to reload.
The co-op community is not as large as I had hoped.
Guards are almost too easy to get past.

So, basically, I had a lot of fun playing this game, though I would recommend getting it on sale.

This game is one of the best buys I've made during my time on steam. The trailer's don't necessarily do the graphics justice, which have really clear visuals, and a minimalistic, but aesthetically pleasing neon art style. The soundtrack is also killer, capturing the perfect tone. The gameplay is fantastic, akin to pacman with stealth, guns, and laser-rigged security systems. There is little in the way of tutorial, so you are left to experiment for yourself,but that works well for this for this game, which has you balance careful planning, against quick thinking and resourcefulness for when things go wrong.

The plot was also pretty fresh, while nodding to tropes within the heist genre. The game offers a lot of replayability too, as though the single player is fun and carries the game by itself, the multiplayer enables you to play with others to try and try to grab everything and get out as fast as possible. In addition to this, the community is pretty good, and new levels are often being made.

Of course, no game is perfect, and if I had to say something, it would be that though the plot was great, it was advanced sparingly from mission to mission. If story is what you look for in a game, this may not be the game for you. Also, although you don't have to collect every coin to win" a mission

reviewText:
So earlier on in the spring, I purchased Monaco for 4 dollars because I needed a break from Skyrim. It is one of those rare indy games that comes around that realizes the best way to reward a player is by cleverness rather than trial and error. It's a game of actual skill and challenge rather than merely repetition and memorization. If I'd known how good it was going to be, I would have bought it at full price.

Monaco is a stealth co-op game where you play a team of 8 thieves in vibrant colors. Together, they work to pull off a heist at Monte Carlo, the largest casino in the world. The world takes place in the actual city of Monaco, which has been stylized in a sort of retro look. Oddly enough, the game actually resembles the city at night. Just an interesting side note there. Anyway, each of the 8 thieves has particular talents which are used to work together with other players. The objective in each mission is varieties of rescuing a team member, collect a bunch of trophies, or just try to make a quick getaway in the van.

Technically, you do not need to play multiplayer to progress, but it's highly recommended for new players as Monaco is significantly easier with three extra pairs of hands. If you do desire to player it single player, I would recommend looking into some player made tutorial missions that'll tell you everything you need to know.

If there's any kind of nitpicking I could have about Monaco, it's that combat is just a major waste of time(unless you are playing in Zombie Mode). When you pick up a gun, you only get one shot and it takes ten coins to get one extra shot of ammo. Most floors in a level have 50 coins on average and there's about 2-3 floors per level. That means you're looking at maybe 10 shots at best...unless you're playing in multiplayer. Only then do things get really antagonistic as four thieves are competing for coins when cleaning out places.

To top that off, even if you do collect all the coins on your own, you'll often find yourself outnumbered and outgunned by guards and civilians and they can all resurrect each other...so there's no real point to the weapons except to buy for more time. For some people who like the option of blasting through everyone who gets in their way, this may be a bit of a turnoff. I don't personally mind it however, because combat is not the focus of Monaco. It's about the caper, the chase, the theft. If you are looking for mindless slaughtering, check out the Zombie Mode. Zombie Mode makes you get twice as much ammo for the coins you collect and even gives the cleaner an one hit kill sneak attack.

Complaints about combat aside, what makes a stealth co-op game like Monaco fun is that you're not scored based on how carefully you stealth. The truth of the matter is security gets so beefed up in the late game that even if you were the greatest cat burglar in the world, you're still eventually going to get caught. But that's part of what makes it so exciting when four thieves are running around like chickens with their heads cut off, collecting all the coins, dodging guards and turret fire while desperately trying to resurrect one another. It's the chaotic elements they add that make it stand out as a stealth game and once you get used to the mechanics on hiding and sneaking, then the game just starts to challenge you.

One recommendation I would say if you choose to buy this is don't play this game for longer than 2 or 3 missions per day. Monaco is like a good wine--great for savouring but not so much for consuming. If you do power through it, the novelty will start to wear off fast and you'll just wind up burning out. There's enough enjoyment from getting 100% coins and no deaths with a competent team of friends in a single mission than teabagging every noob you see in a triple A shooter. It's a game that's all about quality over quantity.

These reasons are all that what makes Monaco a game that totally deserves your attention because it's the indy game of early 2014 that most deserves to be played. They just finished up the last patch on it and it's available on steam for 5 bucks. So stop reading this, go to the store and buy this already. In the meantime, I have more time to play as the Gentleman. :)

The game has a top down view, you have a field of vision (opponents too) and you can see most of the buildings layoutes once you have explored them. You move around with arrow keys and with the help of different character you can go through walls, pick locks or hack computers etc. Your goal is get through security and fine the cake".

For me it’s the coop that really shines since you can have your buddies set up different scenarios or organize traps for the baddies and it’s just a lot of fun.  It’s also the type of game you can easily play with your girlfriend!

9/10 in my book.

reviewText:
Monaco Whats Yours Is Mine

We've all had that fantasy, you know, the one where you plan an elaborate heist, Even if you haven't i'm sure you have at least seen ocean's 11. Sadly if you tried this in real life you would risk going to prison, but fret no more because finally a game has come out where you can do just that (other than payday), without suffering the real life consequences of robbing a bank.

Sound 4/5
Art 5/5
Gameplay 4/5
Story 3/5
Overall 16/20

On the sound spectrum i think I was rather generous as the music is not tremendous (purely my opinion), but there are no horrible sound effects that take away from the experience of the game. Where it really excels in this spectrum is the voice acting. while not much dialogue, the little there is is very funny.

At the quality AAA games are at in this day of age it is hard for small teams to get that same feel, so many go for the retro look. However, just because the graphics aren't of their era doesn't write them off the art category. Even though it may not look real it is still one of most beautifully presented games i have ever seen. they really pushed what they could do with the graphics they had

The gameplay is light, fun and a blast with friends. the high speed robbery is a great mechanic and can only be built on,and with so many different classes to choose from it can take a lot of planning until you and your friends have the perfect bank mugging dream team. you can also go solo if you wish and will still be challenged to a very fun and strategic game. Sometimes you can spend hours trying to get that top spot on the leaderboards and it is a game that suites that competitiveness completely. sadly, this game can get slightly repetitave after playing for a while and the replay value isnt great at this point

The story in this game is good but not great, it is quite simple and engaging but gets quite predictable and you sometimes just skip some dialogues before the level completely. However, the story gets the job done and really is not what this game is focused on. like many retro style games story is an afterthought and that definately shows in Monaco, but it is not bad to a point that it ruins the game

I would recommend this game to anyone who has any taste in games. with all the cookie-cutter fps games there are it is pleasant to see something  innovative and new. It is well worth the money and I think most people would have a good time with it

reviewText: As many people have said, if you look at the disrecommendations, this game is very easy and boring.  However, what those people fail to realize is that, they didn't try hard enough.  This game is so boring and simple if you just run through, grab the objectives, and dodge bullets.  Now, on the other hand, if you actually go for the achievements, try sneaking through undetected, getting every coin, and not dying, it quickly becomes very difficult and fun.  Several people have stated it lacks challenge and strategizing, but that's probably because they played the first levels designed for newcomers, and didn't even try to do good.  My friend and I played through the entire game, getting every trophy and achievement, including a hidden one, and it was not easy at several points.  For example, in one level, guards spawn every 20 seconds, and form giant conga lines of destruction.  Now try sneaking past their unpredictable routes into a guarded room, knocking out the guards without getting seen, so that you can hack a computer and hope that everything works out to let you get through the other 2 rooms, past some lasers, and giving you enough time to grab the cash and get out.  My friend and I got rather good at the game and it took us about 30 tries to get lucky on that level.  This game has tons of gameplay, and even more replayability with the many character combinations and strategies you can use on each level.  I highly recommend this game to anyone.

reviewText: An indie coop heist game.\nAmazingly fun to play in coop with friends online or on a single screen, though it requires X360 gamepads for other players (max 4 players either on- or offline). Great challenge when going solo, especially with the additional task of collecting all the loot. Time spent on each level can be compared with other players via the built-in leaderboards. Not to mention the great, full of twists story, the built-in map editor (steam workshop), good humour (guards' voices), good replay value, additional zombie mode and the free expansion which closes the story. There are a couple of flaws, but they are outnumbered by the sheer fun when playing this. It seems like the developers really loved creating this gem. At least that's what I felt while playing it. reviewText:
Monaco: A really well-rounded stealth game.

The game follows the lives of a band of criminals in Monaco. Main story points are made at the beginning of each level, so don't just skip straight past it on your first play through.

The gameplay is very good and it is well balanced between the Stealthy parts and the parts that may require a more brute force approach. There is also a wealth of tools for you to use whihc lets you customize your gameplay to whichever style you prefer.

The control scheme works very well, I have tested with a controller & keyboard/mouse. The levels in-game give a good explanation of how to use the controls.

There is a surprising amount of detail in the environments, given that it's a 2D top down pixel style. Worthy of note is the lighting algorithm, which limits your line of view depending on where you are in a level.

The sound and music involved are very good. Not too over the top, and it suits the stealth aspect of the game very well.

There is a wide array of workshop content, and included is a simple & easy to use level editor.

I have not yet tested the multiplayer or the pvp aspect of the game, so I cannot comment on it.

While playing this game I found no major bugs, or minor bugs for that matter.

Definitely try this game if you like platformers in the stealth genre. It should give you a few good hours of gameplay for the main gampaign acts, more if you try to get 100% completion on each level.

Monaco is a top-down heist game where you choose one of four characters (with an additional four unlocked as the story progresses), break out of prison, and then with the help of the mysterious Gentleman, attempt to flee Monaco. I'd call this a Stealth game, but the stealth often decays into a mad dash to run out of sight of enemies or to make a mad dash away from the C4 you just placed to blow open a safe or wall or security guard.

It's good in single-player, but where Monaco truly shines is 4-player co-op.

reviewText:
Monaco: What's Yours is mine is a 1-4 player co-op heist game, a lovely 8-bit game where you sneak through locations while trying to steal valuable goods, and is a game I cannot recommend more heartily.  This is one of the indie sensations like Fez and Bastion that were being talked about and were winning awards before the game was even released, so it would be CRIMINAL (pardon the pun) to ignore a game with as much accolades as Monaco.

The gameplay revolves around each level being a bit like a puzzle.  There are guards, security cameras, alarms, motion detectors, and other things that you have to bypass in order to get the gold, documents, or money and escape.  Each player gets to choose a different thief that specializes in different things; every thief can do everything necessary to beat a mission, but the Lockpick can pick locks and safes much faster, the Pickpocket can gather gold much more safely than others, the Mole can break through walls, and so on.  Choosing your specialist comes down to playstyle more than necessity, which is very nice since that means your team can be built around what everyone likes most instead of needing to play this or that character.  This really lets people get into the game by picking the burglar that they think is coolest or most fun.

Important note: By no means is this a game that depends on flawless execution.  The most fun is when the alarm inevitably goes off and you and your friends scramble trying to grab the money and still escape, with an army of guards chasing you the entire way.  These are the most enjoyable moments of the game, where everything has gone wrong and you're still desperately trying to get the money and escape while everyone is laughing and trying to hide and being shot at.  This is definitely a fun little party game, and though the later levels require a little planning, it truly is a great game to play with friends or family of any age.

I cannot recommend this game higher as a co-op game for you and a few friends.  Buy it, bring a friend or two over if you have some controllers, and enjoy Monaco, where What's There is Yours.

Story
-There are a total of 49 story missions divided into 4 campaigns - Locksmith's Story(17 missions), Pickpocket's Story(16 missions), Origins(8 missions), Fin(8 missions). You can choose to do these missions in 3 different modes: Enhanced, Classic, Zombie. reviewText:
Having put 60 hours into this game solo and co-op with an additional 25 hours in creating my own custom mission, I felt it's finally time to leave a quick review. This is a great game for casual gamers like myself. With my short attention span for games nowadays, it's awesome to come across one that is so simple in concept that it is easy to pick up. Missions range from a few minutes to maybe 45 minutes, and it's just perfect.

Even when you're done with the campaigns, there is a plethora of custom missions created by dedicated players. Of course, not all are winners, but there are definitely some very fun ones to play with friends.

And of course, that brings me to the best aspect of this game: Co-op play. It's hard to find great co-op action these days, and Monaco delivers. I just love that you really have to work together to finish, period. If just one player is dead, you simply cannot progress. It's also fun to have to constantly be saving each other's asses...especially when you have a friend who likes to throw himself into the throes of danger just so he can shout WHOOOOOOOOOOO!" And then he gets blasted in the face by shotguns.

As someone who doesn't even play games that much anymore
date: Monaco was a delightful surprise that will keep me playing as long as the custom missions keep coming out."
